examples.text: Is your sister older or younger than you?
Is it a boy or a girl?

definitions.definition: used in negative sentences when mentioning two or more things

examples.text: There are people without homes, jobs or family.

definitions.definition: used to warn or advise somebody that something bad could happen; otherwise

examples.text: Turn the heat down or it'll burn.

definitions.definition: used between two numbers to show approximately how many

examples.text: There were six or seven of us there.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a word or phrase that explains or means the same as another

examples.text: geology, or the science of the earth’s crust
It weighs a kilo, or just over two pounds.

definitions.definition: used to say why something must be true

examples.text: He must like her, or he wouldn't keep calling her.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a different or opposite idea
used when you are not exactly sure about a person, thing or place

examples.text: He's a factory supervisor or something.
‘Who said so?’ ‘Oh, somebody or other. I can't remember who it was.’

wordOrigin: Middle English: a reduced form of the obsolete conjunction other (which superseded Old English oththe ‘or’), of uncertain ultimate origin.
